“They’re making the most of it!” he shouted. 

“Yes, they’ve wept and grown used to it,” he continued. 

“Man grows used to everything, the scoundrel!” 

He sank into thought. 

“What if I am wrong?” he cried suddenly. 

“What if man isn’t a scoundrel? 

What if it’s all prejudice, just artificial terrors?” 

He paused, considering. 

“Maybe there are no barriers. 

Maybe it’s all as it should be.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The narrator reflects on the nature of humanity, questioning whether the perception of man as a scoundrel is merely a prejudice.
